--- Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@...> wrote:
> Some of you may have read our previous Tech Report,
> "Competitive
> Coevolution through Evolutionary Complexification." 
> That paper has
> now been replaced with a much-updated journal paper
> in the Journal of
> Artificial Intelligence Research (JAIR), by the same
> title.  The newer
> paper has been expanded and updated, and includes
> significantly more
> experimental results.  

Cool...thanks for the update, Ken.

I'm interested to read this updated paper.

I had a question about how you implemented your robot
simulation.  Did you do all the simulation stuff from
scratch?

Though we're primarily concentrating on game domains,
we've been looking at robot control as well.  There
are a few good opensource robot simulators out there. 
In Java, there are KSIM and TeamBots:

http://ehrg.cs.wright.edu/ksim/ksim.html
http://www.teambots.org/

I had previously looked at JRobots, but it is not
opensource, and the restrictions for developing the
bots is prohibitive for research.

KSIM models Khepera robots and TeamBots models Nomad
and Cye robots.  TeamBots also includes a SoccerBots
package which pits teams of five against one another,
and it includes a fairly large range of hard-coded
strategies.

Our focus right now is trying to finally get our NEAT
implementation released (we've settled on the name of
ANJI--Another NEAT Java Implementation), but we'd like
to look down the road at a variety of domains to
extend it, and robot simulations seem like a pretty
interesting domain (but we'd rather not code
everything from scratch if we can help it).

I was also wondering if any of the NEAT control
algorithms that you evolved for your robot control
experiments might be portable to a physical robot.  I
notice a professor named Peter Stone there at UT
Austin who seems to be involved in RoboCup competition
with both wheeled and legged robots, both physical and
simulated.  Is there any crossover in what you guys
do?

Derek
